dataset_list.title: Despite incomes growing for the poorest 20% of people, inequality has increased and the gap is projected to widen
In recent years, ODA in support of social/welfare services has accounted for a similar proportion as in the 1990s
Global progress in reducing poverty was mainly driven by a sharp decrease in the number of people living in extreme poverty in East Asia largely as a result of economic growth
In 2030, poverty will become increasingly concentrated in sub-Saharan Africa
Around 30 countries can be identified as most at risk of being left behind based on a combination of poverty, vulnerability and human development indicators
Extreme poverty is increasingly focused in certain subnational areas
Young and older people are more likely to be living in extreme poverty and be left behind
Net ODA has grown in $ terms since the 1960s but not as a share of donors’ GNI
Since 1970, some donors have seen falling levels of ODA as a % of GNI, but most have increased their proportions
An additional US$1.5 trillion of ODA could be disbursed by 2030 if all donors achieved 0.7% by 2030
The proportion of ODA allocated to specific countries has fallen rapidly in recent years
ODA spent within donor countries and not allocated to specific developing countries has risen rapidly
Of the ODA allocated to specific countries, more than half goes to countries in sub-Saharan Africa and South and Central Asia (US$ bn, %)
There is only a small difference in proportions of ODA received by countries with the highest and the lowest levels of extreme poverty
(left): Although more ODA goes to countries with more poor people…

and Figure 2.9: 2 Bar Charts, 1st depicting ODA funding amounts (in US$ billions) by numbers of people in extreme poverty, 2nd depicting proportional amount per poor person by the same groupings. 2016 figures.
(right):…the amounts are nowhere near proportional  to the scale of poverty
More ODA goes to countries with lower countries with low government resources…
…however, ODA per poor person is significantly in lower government revenues
Growth in ODA to LDCs has lagged behind overall ODA growth
ODA to countries identified as being left behind is flatlining while ODA spent elsewhere is growing
Adaptation ODA is not effectively targeting the people most vulnerable to climate change
5: Loans have grown much faster than other forms of ODA in recent years
Large amounts of ODA loans in 2016 went to countries with high poverty levels…
…and to countries with low government revenue
The flow of ODA in 2016 (US$ bn)
Overall, most ODA is channelled via public-sector bodies
Less ODA is channelled through the public sector in countries being left behind
Humanitarian aid has grown much more quickly than other ODA since 2012
Proportions of ODA to Education, Other social services and General budget support have fallen
There are clear differences across sector allocations of ODA between countries at different levels of extreme poverty
Sector allocations of ODA to countries being left behind and other developing countries differ, but social protection remains among the lowest for both
Since 2002, ODA to countries being left behind has become increasingly concentrated on health and humanitarian interventions, while budget support and aid to business and education has fallen
Total development cooperation from other government providers stood at US$25 billion in 2016
In aggregate, all international financing flows have been increasing with private flows increasing the fastest overall
Non-ODA flows are far smaller where poverty is greatest and where domestic public resources are lowest
Excluding ODA, countries most at risk of being left behind receive the least international financing (per capita)
The combined portfolios of European DFIs have grown by 86% between 2009 and 2016
Non-ODA financing targets infrastructure and business and industry more than social sectors
Districts with the highest poverty tend to have proportionally less resources
Bar chart depicting values (US$ billions) for domestic resources in developing countries and international finance inflows and outflows by sector. Figures for year 2016.
Domestic resources in developing countries are 12 times larger than international finance flows to developing countries, of which commercial sources of finance dominate
Commercial long-term debt and FDI are the two largest sources of international financing to developing countries
In aggregate, domestic public resources have increased by 55% since 2008 but growth has slowed
Domestic public resources are lowest where extreme poverty is highest
Countries being left behind will see slower growth in domestic public resources than other developing countries
In many sub-Saharan African countries there is potential to grow the tax base, but also a need to increase tax potential
Various initiatives are pushing for the opening of domestic and international data sources
The availability and openness of development data varies across different dimensions of sustainable development

introduces a conceptual model framework that can be used to prioritise efforts in specific contexts. At each stage of delivery (planning, implementation and evaluation) it assesses demand for data at local, national and international levels, and an indication of where the challenges of both supply and use of the data are most urgent. Drawing on limited available case study evidence for this report, it then applies the framework to identify where key challenges
The extent and urgency of challenges related to data use can be measured across levels of intervention and stages of delivery
Business as usual means uneven and unequal progress for people
For countries being left behind – both ODA and other external sources will fail to close the gap
This challenge is likely to be most acute in countries furthest behind. It highlights the challenges in education – a fundamental enabler of long-term development and economic growth.
Business as usual will leave many poverty-critical sectors like education underfunded particularly in those countries furthest behind
Since 2000, domestic commercial resources have grown substantially but, excluding China, growth has been slowing down
Domestic commercial resources are lowest where poverty is highest
Most Filipino business investments targeted SDGs 11 (34%) and 4 (28%)
